sen.j: 藤原 彰子（ふじわら の あきこ（しょうし）、永延2年（988年） - 承保元年10月3日 (旧暦)（1074年10月25日）は、第66代一条天皇の皇后（号は中宮）で、第68代後一条天皇・第69代後朱雀天皇の生母（国母）、女院。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Akiko (Shoshi) (988-October 25, 1074) was the empress (Chugu) of 66th Emperor Ichijio and a mother (Kokumo, Nyoin) of 68th Emperor Goichijo and 69th Emperor Suzaku.
FUJIWARA no Akiko (Shoshi) (988-October 25, 1074) was the empress (Chugu - or consort) of 66th Emperor Ichijio and the mother (Kokumo, Nyoin) of the 68th Emperor Goichijo and the 69th Emperor Suzaku.

Empress FUJIWARA no Akiko (her given name can also be pronounced "Shoshi") (988 - October 25, 1074) was the chugu (a court title given to a consort of the Emperor) of the sixty-sixth Emperor, Ichijio, and the mother of the sixty-eighth Emperor, Goichijo, and the sixty-ninth Emperor, Gosuzaku (she also held the title Kokumo, meaning empress dowager, and Nyoin).
sen.cmt: Some explanations were needed in places, I think.Also, a comma is grammatically required between "66th Emperor" and "Ichijio", for example. Otherwise this means that there have been 65 Emperor Ichijios prior to this one.スペース挿入Suzaku→Gosuzaku

sen.cmt: Grammatically, "revered titles" means that the title itself is revered rather than the person.

sen.j: 女房に『源氏物語』の作者・紫式部、王朝有数の歌人・和泉式部、歌人で『栄花物語』正編の作者と伝えられる赤染衛門、同じく歌人の伊勢大輔などを従え、華麗な文芸サロンを形成した。
sen.e: Her female attendants included "The Tale of Genji" author, Murasaki Shikibu, the prominent poet of the dynasty, Izumi Shikibu (who is the possible author of "Eiga Monogatari"), poet Akazome Emon, and poet Ise no Taifu who formed flamboyant literature salon.

She had several literary ladies-in-waiting, including "The Tale of Genji" author, Murasaki Shikibu; the greatest poet of her time, Izumi Shikibu; the poet Akazome Emon (who is the possible author of "Eiga Monogatari") and the poet Ise no Taifu.

She outlived two of her grandchildren, Goreizei and Emperor Gosanjo, who contributed to the demise of the Regent system built up by her father.

sen.j: 彼女は比較的に多くの和歌を残したが、なかでも後一条天皇の死後に詠んだ「ひと声も君に告げなんほととぎす この五月雨は闇にまどふと」等、夫や子供の死を悼んだ歌が多い。
sen.e: She left fairly many waka (Japanese poem) but especially those poems that mourned the death of her husband and children such as 'Hitokoto mo Kimini tsugenan hototgisu kono samidare wa yamini madofuto (Please tell my late son even just a single word, hototogisu (lesser cuckoo), that I am shrouded in darkness thinking about my child in this summer rain)' read after the death of Emperor Goichijo.

sen.e: Her death came 8 months after the death of her younger brother Yorimichi on February 2 of the same year.
